A subring $T$ of a field $K$ is called a subfield if $T$ is a field itself.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Does the concept of a/an Subfield need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand whether the concept of a subfield needs to be defined for the definition of a Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension to make sense, we need to analyze the components of the definition of the Galois Group. The definition of the Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension involves the concept of a field extension, specifically $\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q$. This notation inherently implies that $\mathbb{F}_q$ is a subfield of $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$. The definition of the Galois Group also includes the requirement that the automorphisms fix $\mathbb{F}_q$, which means they leave every element of $\mathbb{F}_q$ unchanged while possibly changing elements of $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$ that are not in $\mathbb{F}_q$. This fixing condition is meaningful only if $\mathbb{F}_q$ is understood to be a subfield of $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$. Therefore, the concept of a subfield is essential to understanding what it means for these automorphisms to fix $\mathbb{F}_q$, and thus, it is necessary for the definition of the Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension to be fully comprehensible.
